column9: BOIL WATER ORDER LIFTED FOR SEVERAL ADDRESSES IN SLOATSBURG AND TUXEDO

column1: By dskriloff on July 8, 2014 Comments
<article class=""entry post-24795 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-breaking-news last_archivepost"" itemscope="""" itemtype=""http://schema.org/NewsArticle"">
Share on Facebook
Follow on Facebook
Add to Google+
Connect on Linked in
Subscribe by Email
Print This Post
United Water received official notification from the Rockland County Health Department that enables the boil water order to be lifted for customers at the following locations:
· In Sloatsburg– the area north of Washington Avenue along the Route 17 corridor as well as all residences on Park Avenue and Whrittenour Terrace.
· In Tuxedo– the following addresses on RT 17: # 9, 15, # 21,(Tuxedo Manor Apts #1-16), #31 (Tuxedo Manor Apts # 1-16.)
The boil water order was issued on July 4 as a precautionary measure following a break on an 8-inch water main on Route 17.

Customers were ordered to boil water as a precautionary measure while United Water emergency crews restored water service and water quality tests were performed. Lab results indicate that the water meets all safe drinking water standards.

“We recognize that a boil water order is an inconvenience to our customers and we thank them for their patience during this time,” said Michael Pointing, vice president and general manager of United Water.

<a class=""save-list-a761f304-06cc-11e4-8d12-0019bb2963f4-btn save-asset "" href=""#"" onclick=""jQuery('.save-list-a761f304-06cc-11e4-8d12-0019bb2963f4-form').submit(); return false;"" rel=""nofollow"" role=""button"" title=""Save to list"">
GLENS FALLS -- A boil-water notice has been issued for residents and business owners on Broad Street, between North Delaware and Murray Street, because of a water main break.

This precautionary order was issued at 4:30 p.m. Monday and will be in effect for a minimum of two days. There have been no tests that indicate the water is not usable, but the state Department of Health is recommending residents in this area boil their water until all tests are negative for E. coli.

The city will notify residents who live on Broad Street between North Delaware and Murray Street when the order has been lifted.

Call the Water and Sewer Department at 761-3850 with any questions.

11 Long Island beaches closed to swimming Saturday

column2: Located along Bayville Avenue, Soundside Beach Park in Bayville features a small stretch of beach on the Long Island Sound, a volleyball court, and playground. The park is only open to Bayville residents. (July 10, 2013) Photo Credit: Tara Conry

column1: Tweet
Share
Email
Eleven Long Island beaches were closed to swimming Saturday due to concerns about bacteria levels.

Nassau County health officials ordered 10 North Shore beaches and one South Shore beach closed after officials cited the heavy rains that generate stormwater runoff, which can sweep bacteria and pathogens into local streams and bays, causing levels to spike.

The North Shore beaches are Centre Island Sound, Creek Club, Lattingtown Beach, Laurel Hollow Beach, Piping Rock Beach Club, Pryibil Beach, Ransom Beach, Theodore Roosevelt Beach, Soundside Beach and Stehli Beach. Also, Biltmore Beach Club in Massapequa remained closed from earlier elevated bacterial levels, officials said.

Field 6 at West Beach and Field 8 at Overlook Beach, both at Heckscher State Park in East Islip, reopened to swimming Saturday after having been closed due to unacceptable water quality, the state Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation said. Field 6 at West Beach had been closed since Thursday.
For recorded information on beach closings and openings in Nassau, call 516-227-9700. Health department representatives are available weekdays, from 9 a.m. to 4:45 p.m., at 516-227-9717.

Boil-water order lifted for Sloatsburg, Tuxedo

The order to boil water, prompted by a break in a water main, affects a small number of residents.

Boil-water order lifted for Sloatsburg, Tuxedo

Ned P. Rauch, erauch@lohud.com

Published 9:09 a.m. ET July 4, 2014 | Updated 8:14 a.m. ET July 9, 2014
Buy Photo

LH Logo: Breaking News(Photo: The Journal News)Buy Photo

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

July 9 update: The boil water advisory has been lifted.

SLOATSBURG – Rockland County health officials have issued a boil water order in pockets of Sloatsburg and Tuxedo following a break in a water main.

The order affects residents living on Orange Turnpike, Park Avenue and Whrittenour Terrace in the village of Sloatsburg as well as some Tuxedo residents who live on Route 17 and in the Tuxedo Manor Apartments complex.

According to a statement from United Water, residents affected by the order should boil water for one minute if they plan to use it for drinking or cooking purposes.

Madeline Power, a spokeswoman for United Water, said an 8-inch water main running beneath Route 17 broke Thursday evening. Crews worked through the night to repair the rupture, finishing their work early Friday morning. Power said the utility has notified affected residents and will let them know when the water is once again safe to drink.

For more information, visit http://www.unitedwater.com/cusNewscenter.aspx?id=10790

Boil-water order lifted for Sloatsburg, Tuxedo

The order to boil water, prompted by a break in a water main, affects a small number of residents.

Boil-water order lifted for Sloatsburg, Tuxedo

Ned P. Rauch, erauch@lohud.com

Published 9:09 a.m. ET July 4, 2014 | Updated 8:14 a.m. ET July 9, 2014
Buy Photo

LH Logo: Breaking News(Photo: The Journal News)Buy Photo

CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

July 9 update: The boil water advisory has been lifted.

SLOATSBURG – Rockland County health officials have issued a boil water order in pockets of Sloatsburg and Tuxedo following a break in a water main.

The order affects residents living on Orange Turnpike, Park Avenue and Whrittenour Terrace in the village of Sloatsburg as well as some Tuxedo residents who live on Route 17 and in the Tuxedo Manor Apartments complex.

According to a statement from United Water, residents affected by the order should boil water for one minute if they plan to use it for drinking or cooking purposes.

Madeline Power, a spokeswoman for United Water, said an 8-inch water main running beneath Route 17 broke Thursday evening. Crews worked through the night to repair the rupture, finishing their work early Friday morning. Power said the utility has notified affected residents and will let them know when the water is once again safe to drink.

For more information, visit http://www.unitedwater.com/cusNewscenter.aspx?id=10790

Purpose: Load Paragraph for the article.
JANESVILLE—Lions Beach, 1401 Palmer Drive, is closed until further notice due to elevated bacteria levels found in the swimming area, according to a city news release.
The city recreation division's weekly water sample results were more than 1,000 ppm of bacteria, requiring the swimming area to be closed because of water quality standards.
The recent sample was taken when water was warm, which could make results uncertain. Recreation division staff will re-sample “properly-iced” water today, according to the release.
If the new sample is approved by the state hygiene lab in Madison, the beach with be reopened.
Weekly water samples are taken to monitor E. coli bacteria. All previous water results at the beach from 2014 have been safe for swimming.

Boil Order No Longer in Effect in Oak Grove Area
<div aria-hidden=""true"" aria-labelledby=""modalTitle"" class=""reveal-modal"" data-reveal="""" id=""modal-magnify-photo-"" role=""dialog"">
<div aria-hidden=""true"" class=""f-dropdown content medium"" data-dropdown-content="""" id=""drop-geocode"" tabindex=""-1"">

UPDATE: The boil order has ended.

The water samples have been cleared by the Department of Health and Hospitals.

The water is now safe to use, according to officials.

------------------------------------------

OAK GROVE, La. -- The Goodwill Water System is under a boil order.

Customers on Highway 585 South, from Goodwill on Highway 2 to Bouef Wiver, Prince Road, River Road, Clear Lake Road, All of Watts Road, Burkett Road, Babcock Road, and Benton Road will be under a boil order until notified.

The water on these roads is being cutoff on Tuesday for repair until the lines are fixed.

The company says if you are on these roads, you need to have water to drink until repairs are made.

Water will need to be boiled for one full minute before use in a clean container.

The one minute starts after the water has been brought to a rolling boil.

Some Loves Park residents under drinking water boil

LOVES PARK – Some Loves Park residents are under a boil order for drinking water after a water pressure drop in the village’s distribution system.

The Loves Park Water Department said residents in an area north of Windsor Road, south of Route 173, west of Perryville Road and east of Alpine Road are affected.

Residents in the area are advised to boil water for five minutes before consuming it. A drop in system water pressure can allow bacteria into a water supply and be carried to consumers.

The boil order is in effect until 7 a.m. Tuesday.

For more information, call the water department 815-877-1421 between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m.

– Brian Leaf

Weather Forecast
TOWN OF THOMPSON – The state Health
Department has lifted the boil-water order it imposed on June 23 for residents
of the Cold Spring Water District in the Town of Thompson.
Analysis of water samples collected from the facility on three days earlier
this month reflected high levels of coliform bacteria.
But the state agency on Friday lifted the order saying testing on June
25 and 26 indicted the water supply “to be of a satisfactory bacteriological
quality at the time of the sampling.”
Harmful microbes in drinking water can cause diarrhea, cramps, nausea,

Boil water order in Anderson County canceled

<div class=""share-content js-share-container article-social"" data-content-title=""Boil water order in Anderson County canceled"" data-content-url=""/article/boil-water-order-in-anderson-county-canceled/7009430"">

ANDERSON COUNTY, S.C. —

A boil water order in Anderson County has been cancelled, according to Anderson Regional Joint Water System.

The advisory was issued Wednesday after a failure at a pump station when it comes to the intake from Lake Hartwell to the treatment facility, according to Anderson County officials.

The advisory did include residents of the West Anderson Water District, Hammond Water District, town of Pendleton, Sandy Springs Water District, town of Williamston, Big Creek Water District, city of Clemson, Clemson University, Electric City Utilities, Homeland Park, Star-Iva Water district and Broadway Water.

Questions/concerns

Anyone with questions concerning the notice should call the Joint Water System at 864-226-9676.

<a href=""mailto:?subject=Boil order issued for sections of Olive, Mercer streets&body=http://www.goshennews.com/news/boil-order-issued-for-sections-of-olive-mercer-streets/article_94440011-d612-5655-aecb-7e3a16f03e51.html"" style=""padding:10px"">

Goshen officials have issued a boil water order for residents/businesses along Olive Street from Center Street to Lincoln Avenue and Mercer Avenue from North Ninth Street to Olive Street.

Utility crews shut down a water main to replace broken water valves at 7 this morning.

The Indiana Department of Environmental Management requires that the utility issue a boil water order for the affected area.

After the water valves are replaced, two consecutive water samples will need to be taken and analyzed for the presence of bacteria. If those tests pass, the boil order will be lifted.

Notice of the cancellation will be distributed through a customer flier and through The Goshen News.

For more information or to report specific service concerns, contact Mindy Kyle at the Goshen Water Department at 534-5306.

Water should not be consumed unless boiled as instructed by utility officials. The water remains safe for bathing, laundry and restroom facilities. Cleaning dishes with a dishwasher is acceptable if it has a sanitizing cycle. Hand-washed dishes should be rinsed with boiled or bottled water.

:""\/resources\/media\/fc3e84f5-25ba-4582-8cc1-19bb62f2c873-Boil20Advisory.jpg?1439457105737""}},""filter"":null,""domainUrl"":null,""sectionPath"":null,""type"":""story"",""galleryAllowed"":true,""teaserPlacementModified"":false,""leadStoryPlacementModified"":false,""sponsored"":false,""brandUuid"":""64142267-8f95-4b90-b318-eca0eae47225"",""locale"":""en_US"",""storyHash"":null,""syndication"":null,""richText"":""<p>Customers of Consolidated Water in Southern Boone County are being advised to boil their water until Tuesday due to a water main break.{\/p}<p>According to the water district, customers south of Highway H are affected, including those in Hartsburg, Wilton, Englewood, and Claysville.{\/p}<p>Officials say the water main broke on a large transmission pipe at about 8:30 Thursday evening. Crews are flushing and monitoring disinfectant levels in the area.{\/p}<p>Customers are advised to boil water vigorously for at least three minutes before drinking, brushing teeth, or preparing food.{\/p}<p>Do not use ice from an automatic icemaker, and disinfect dishes with water containing a teaspoon of bleach per gallon of water.{\/p}<p>The boil order is in effect until noon Tuesday.{\/p}""};

of Consolidated Water in Southern Boone County are being advised to boil their water until Tuesday due to a water main break.{\/p}<p>According to the water district, customers south of Highway H are affected, including those in Hartsburg, Wilton, Englewood, and Claysville.{\/p}<p>Officials say the water main broke on a large transmission pipe at about 8:30 Thursday evening. Crews are flushing and monitoring disinfectant levels in the area.{\/p}<p>Customers are advised to boil water vigorously for at least three minutes before drinking, brushing teeth, or preparing food.{\/p}<p>Do not use ice from an automatic icemaker, and disinfect dishes with water containing a teaspoon of bleach per gallon of water.{\/p}<p>The boil order is in effect until noon Tuesday.{\/p}""},""rendering"":{""adZone"":""news\/local"",""webAdZoneRoot"":""Web"",""mobileAdZoneRoot"":""Mobile"",""dfpNetworkId"":""4756"",""dfpAdUnitId"":""KRCG"",""faviconImageUrl"":""\/resources\/assets\/krcg\/images\/logos\/favicon.ico"",""pageTitle"":""Boil Boil order in effect for Consolidated customers

by Dan Claxton

Customers of Consolidated Water in Southern Boone County should boil their water until Tuesday.

Fri, 27 Jun 2014 15:49:26 GMT — 

Customers of Consolidated Water in Southern Boone County are being advised to boil their water until Tuesday due to a water main break.

According to the water district, customers south of Highway H are affected, including those in Hartsburg, Wilton, Englewood, and Claysville.

Officials say the water main broke on a large transmission pipe at about 8:30 Thursday evening. Crews are flushing and monitoring disinfectant levels in the area.

Customers are advised to boil water vigorously for at least three minutes before drinking, brushing teeth, or preparing food.

Do not use ice from an automatic icemaker, and disinfect dishes with water containing a teaspoon of bleach per gallon of water.

The boil order is in effect until noon Tuesday.

BPW lifts boil order over 20 hours early

column5: Following acceptable water quality tests, the Hannibal Board of Public Works on Thursday afternoon lifted the city-wide mandatory boil order that had been in place since Monday.

column1: Following acceptable water quality tests, the Hannibal Board of Public Works on Thursday afternoon lifted the city-wide mandatory boil order that had been in place since Monday.
Following acceptable water quality tests, the Hannibal Board of Public Works on Thursday afternoon lifted the city-wide mandatory boil order that had been in place since Monday.
The BPW officially announced the boil order was lifted at 4:20 p.m., just under 21 hours earlier than had been anticipated.
“Everything looks good,” said Heath Hall, director of operations for the BPW, regarding the bacteria testing done on water samples taken at 10 sites throughout the city’s water system on Wednesday.

When the boil order was originally announced Monday it was to have been lifted Wednesday. However, the decision was made to extend the boil order after water tests Tuesday revealed there were either very low levels of chlorine in the system, or none at all in some locations. Steps typically taken by the BPW to deal with low chlorine levels could not be taken because of low water levels in the city’s storage tanks.

On Wednesday, chlorine levels were found to be at acceptable levels at all test sites but near Hannibal Regional Hospital, which happens to be the farthest point in the city’s water system from the Water Filter Plant. To enhance chlorine levels in that area three fire hydrants were allowed to run near the hospital on Wednesday, to pull in chlorinated water from the Filter Plant. That process, known as “flushing,” was stopped sooner than expected, according to Hall.
“We were losing too much ground in the (water storage) tank,” he said.

However, water samples taken as the hydrants were being shut off showed an ample level of chlorine. Bacteria tests, which take 24 hours to run their course, revealed acceptable results both in the area of the hospital and throughout the city.

As one might expect, the BPW has been busy responding to questions posted on its Facebook page. One person asked how long it would take until the water in Ralls County would be safe to drink once the boil order was lifted. The BPW reported that the “water is safe to consume and use normally” after the order was cancelled.
“There is no delay once we give the notice,” responded the BPW.

News that the boil order has been lifted early will likely be applauded by some of the BPW’s industrial customers, who had stopped production once the boil order and request to conserve water was issued early in the week. According to Hall, while some companies resumed their work once the water conservation warning was cancelled Wednesday, some involved in food processing would wait until the boil order was lifted, too.

Problems at the Filter Plant arose between 3:30 p.m. and 4 p.m. Sunday when an electric valve malfunctioned. The valve opened when it should have been closed, allowing the lower level of the Filter Plant, which is filled with an assortment of equipment necessary to process river water, to flood. Before the contents of a storage tank could be turned off, water was literally pouring out the doors of the Filter Plant.
Hall reports that operations are slowly returning to normal at the plant.
“Lots of equipment is up and running, although many valves are still being operated manually,” he said. “A lot of the monitoring equipment which got wet has been replaced.”
As for the large valve which initially malfunctioned, Hall reports the device itself is “fine,” but its electronic actuator will have to be replaced.
“We’re still dealing with insurance and waiting for parts to come in,” he said.
